headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Xylem Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Phil De Sousa, Vice President of Investor Relations.
componenttext: Welcome to the Xylem Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Phil De Sousa, Vice President of Investor Relations.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, Jackie. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Xylem's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. With me today are Chief Executive Officer, Patrick Decker;  And Interim Chief Financial Officer, Shashank Patel. They'll provide their persp
componenttext:
Well, thanks, Jackie. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Xylem's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. With me today are Chief Executive Officer, Patrick Decker;  And Interim Chief Financial Officer, Shashank Patel. They'll provide their perspective on Xylem's fourth quarter and full year 2015 results and discuss the full year outlook for 2016. Following our prepared remarks, we will address questions related to information covered on the call. So that we will have enough time to adjust everyone on the call, we ask that you please keep at least one question and follow up and then return to the queue. We anticipate that today's call will last approximately 1 hour. 
As a reminder, this call of our webcast are accompanied by a slide presentation available in the Investor Section of our website at www.xyleminc.com. A replay of today's call will be available until midnight, on March 6. Please note, the replay number is (800) 585 8367 and the confirmation ID number is 19530850. 
Additionally, the call will be available for playback via the Investor Section of our website under the heading Presentations. Please turn to Slide 2. 
We will make some forward looking statements on today's call including references to future events or developments that we anticipate will or may occur. These statements are subject to future risks and uncertainties, such as those factors described in Xylem's most recent Annual Report on Form 10 K and in subsequent reports filed with the SEC. Please note the company undertakes no obligation to update any forward looking statements publicly to reflect subsequent events or circumstances, and actual events or results could differ materially from those anticipated.  
Please turn to Slide 3. Just a few keynotes for today's representation. All references today will be on an adjusted basis, unless otherwise indicated, and non GAAP financials are reconciled for you in the Appendix section of the presentation. Additionally, please note that references to 2016 metrics include the financial impacts attributable to previously closed acquisitions and have been adjusted to exclude nonrecurring transaction costs. 
Now please turn to Slide 4. I'll turn the call over to our CEO, Patrick Decker.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Phil, and good morning, everyone. Over the course of 2015, we faced a dynamic economic environment on a macrolevel and in key end markets. I'm quite pleased with our teams performance as we remain focused on executing against our long term objec
componenttext:
Thanks, Phil, and good morning, everyone. 
Over the course of 2015, we faced a dynamic economic environment on a macrolevel and in key end markets. I'm quite pleased with our teams performance as we remain focused on executing against our long term objectives. We responded effectively to changing conditions and ultimately closed out the year with another quarter of solid results. We delivered at or above our guidance on several key metrics. 
Organic revenue grew 2% in the quarter, resulting in 2% organic revenue growth for the full year as well. Adjusted earnings per share increased 3% to $0.60 in the quarter, excluding foreign exchange translation. This brought our full year adjusted earnings to $1.85 per share, a 5% increase year over year excluding foreign exchange translation and we delivered free cash flow conversion of 105% delivered by working capital improvement. Importantly, I'm encouraged by the fundamentals and underlying trends impacting our business today and in the years ahead.
External factors such a steadily increasing spend on Water Infrastructure, growing demand for intelligent monitoring and control systems and client related initiatives that require our water expertise and ingenuity all bode well for sustained profitable growth at Xylem.
As we continue to advance the key growth initiatives we laid during our Investor Day last year, namely stepping up our commercial leadership, driving accelerated growth in emerging markets and increasing our investment in R&D and innovation, I'm confident we are well positioned to deliver that growth.
That work will be complemented by our ongoing focus on continuous improvement and business simplication, which will be significant levers for long term value creation. Xylem has a balanced global portfolio that we expect will further benefit from a number of current and emerging trends. Here are couple of the examples. 
The perennial battle to increase spending on Water Infrastructure is gaining some traction here in the U.S. A number of efforts are underway to produce actionable plans to break through the historical barriers of financing, political risk and competing priorities. The urgency of the need is further punctuated by flashpoints such as the tragic situation of Michigan and the flooding events that continue to occur in various parts of the country. Xylem is actively engaged in several of these efforts, including those that are focused on unlocking private capital for infrastructure investment. 
In addition, on the heels on the Paris climate talks, governments around the world are developing action plans to achieve the carbon emission reduction they signed onto in that historic agreement. Given the that the management of water is a notable contributor to global carbon emissions, the water industry has substantial opportunity to contribute to emission reduction goals. 
In light of that, last quarter we issued a report titled Powering the Wastewater Renaissance. This study outlines how the adoption of the readily available wastewater management technologies can cut related emissions by nearly  half. The analysis further concludes that 95% of the electricity related emissions abatement can be achieved at negative or neutral cost, resulting in a win win scenario for our customers as well as the governing bodies that are seeking viable solutions to implement in the near term. 
We believe these activities are positive indicators for the continued recovery we see in the public utility market, which constitutes roughly 1/3 of our global business. Improving market conditions and our strong execution enabled us to gain market share in this end market as we generated 8% organic growth in the fourth quarter. This follows a solid performance in the third quarter when we delivered 5% year over year growth.
The industrial end market is also significant for Xylem. Similar to other companies in this space, we continued to experience the impact of some negative underlying market trends. For the full year, overall industrial was down 1% organically. This however, was largely driven by the steep declines in oil and gas, which was down 40% in 2015 with most of the impact sold in the second half of the year. 
To be clear, despite the fact that oil and gas represented a relatively small portion of our business, the combination of such a severe drop and its high profit margin resulted in a significant impact on our 2015 results. Specifically, oil and gas reduced our revenues by approximately 1%, compressed our operating margin by 40 basis points, and reduced our earnings per share by $0.12. 
Looking ahead, we expect those headwinds to continue at least until we begin to lap the initial declines we first experienced in the second quarter of last year. Then, we anticipate the headwind to moderate somewhat in the second half of the year. 
Overall, we anticipate challenging conditions in oil and gas to continue, but the impact should not be as severe as it was last year. In addition, we expect ongoing headwinds in the mining sector. Collectively, these 2 sectors now represent about 8% of our total revenue. We will continue to manage and ultimately optimize efficiency and performance through the inevitable economic cycles that occur within this end market.
Fortunately, Xylem is better positioned than many. Our industrial market exposure is more heavily weighted to the light industrial sector. In fact, that represents roughly 36% of our total revenue. The benefits of this sector mix are evident in our 2015 results. 
Excluding the severe impact of the oil and gas declines, the remainder of our industrial related business grew 2% for the full year. Driving this growth was the continued demand for industrial water applications such as pressure boosting equipment cooling and fire suppression. Critical nature of these products and services and maintaining operations creates more resilience in the light industrial sector, providing a counterweight to the cyclical volatility seen in heavy industrials. 
One final point, the leading position rehab in certain consumer demand driven applications such as beverage dispensing and marine in RV pump applications helped us deliver solid growth. With combined revenue of more than $120 million, these businesses grew 4% in 2015 and are well positioned to continue growing in 2016. 
From a regional perspective, we remained optimistic about the U.S. markets, particularly the public utility and commercial building sectors, which we'll address in more detail later on the call. Europe is stabilizing and we expect a more favorable outlook there. We had a strong presence in the public utility market in Europe and we're already seeing early signs of success with key product launches in the residential and commercial building sectors. 
The emerging markets present a more complex story. As all of you know, many of these markets are already showing signs of slower growth. After posting 9% organic growth during the first 9 months of the year, our business is in emerging markets grew 2% in the fourth quarter. There are a few dynamics at play here. 
First, the 2% organic growth compared with 14% organic growth in the prior year period. Underlying this delta is a pattern of choppy project deliveries that can easily cause distortions in quarterly year over year growth.
Second, our Applied Water segment declined 4% in the emerging markets in the quarter driven in part by the slowdown in China's industrial and commercial markets. However, given our business in China is more heavily weighted to the public utility end market, we do expect continued growth ahead albeit at a slower pace than in most recent years. 
Shifting gears now. As I've mentioned previously, we are still in the early chapters of a multiyear self help story that will enable us to drive margin expansion. Our continuous improvement initiatives, which include lean and global procurement, along with a sharper focus on driving business simplification, will result in significant operating margin improvement.
Today, G&A cost sit at 8.5% of revenue, down 120 basis points over the past 2 years, but still an opportunity. We will continue to attack these costs in 2016 and beyond as we execute the business simplification plan we laid out at Investor Day, targeting $60 million to $75 million of structural cost reduction over the next few years. Our expectation is to invest approximately $25 million in 2016 from which we anticipate realizing $8 million in savings in the second half of the year and $15 million on an annualized basis. We will touch on this in more detail later in the call.
We are driving productivity within the business so we can fund the necessary investments to achieve our longer term objectives. This includes increasing our R&D investments for future growth, the targeted investment in the Middle East, China and India we highlighted at our Investor Day and accelerating capital deployment on 2 fronts; returning capital to shareholders and acquisitions. 
Today, we announced a 10% increase in dividend and the acquisition of Tideland Corporation, our second acquisition in as many quarters. Let's turn to Slide 5 and I'll cover capital deployment and the Tideland acquisition in more detail.
With our strong cash flow generation and capital structure, we are well positioned to create more value for our shareholders. During the fourth quarter, we repurchased 1.4 million shares for $50 million. For the full year, we repurchased 5.1 million shares for $175 million and we have about $430 million available under our authorized programs.
We also paid $25 million in dividends to shareholders in the quarter, bringing our full year total to $102 million, reflecting a 10% increase per share year over year.
Combined, this represents a 24% increase in return of capital to shareholders in 2015. Earlier this week, we completed our acquisition of Tideland, a leading producer of smart analytic solutions in the coastal and ocean management sectors. More specifically, the company integrate systems intelligence technologies with tools to enable a wide variety of marine and environmental monitoring capabilities to an array of customers. These offerings stood well with our existing analytics portfolio. We intend to further integrate analytics tools from our current portfolio into their systems, including a direct tie in with our recent fourth quarter acquisition, high pack[ph].
The result will be a broader range of systems intelligence solutions that we can provide to the coastal and ocean water sector. Growth in this area will continue to be driven by the customer's need to comply with increasing regulations for a variety of operations in this space.
The acquisitions of Tideland and high pack [ph]  Illustrate how we plan to bring together distinct products and services to build intelligent full systems capability and significantly expand the market we currently serve. 
With that, let me turn the call over to our Interim CFO, Shashank Patel, to walk you through the results and the company's financial position in more detail. Shashank?

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Patrick, and since you already covered some of these full year highlights, I'll make specific points and then dive further into our fourth quarter results. For the full year, revenue increased 2% on an organic basis consistent with the midpoint
componenttext:
Thanks, Patrick, and since you already covered some of these full year highlights, I'll make specific points and then dive further into our fourth quarter results. 
For the full year, revenue increased 2% on an organic basis consistent with the midpoint of our guidance at the beginning of last year. We saw solid growth in the public utility, commercial and residential markets, all up 4% organically. Industrial was down 1%, primarily due to the significant declines we saw in oil and gas over the second half of the year. Agriculture was down 8% as unfavorable weather maybe the severe flooding conditions in the southern U.S. wiped out this year season. As a reminder, higher culture represents 2% of our revenues. Regenerated strongest growth in the emerging markets posted 7% increase over the course of the year. China led the way here growing 14%. Worth noting is that our Water Infrastructure segment grew 17%, driving 80% of the overall growth as the local trend to invest in and improve water quality and wastewater treatment continued.
The U.S. and Western Europe markets grew each grew 1%.
In the U.S., growth accelerated over the course of the year and hit a high for the year in the fourth quarter whereas Europe was relatively stable throughout the year. Canada runs out our geographic performance. There are significant declines in oil and gas resulted in a 13% decline in revenue. 
As for margins, productivity actions and volume leverage more than offset material labor and overhead inflation and unfavorable mix. Excluding FX translation, gross margin expanded 40 basis points and led to a 30 basis point improvement in operating margins. Embedded in this operating margin performance is an investment in selling capabilities in key growth markets, partially offset by a reduction in G&A costs. We reported earnings per share this year of $1.85, an increase of 5% excluding the unfavorable $0.22 impact from foreign exchange translation.
Just a reminder that this 5% increase is on top of the 18% growth and record EPS in 2014, a solid indicator that we have sent Xylem on the right path to improve financial returns. Another similar indicator is our free cash flow performance. This year, we generated to $347 million, an increase of 17%. We also achieved a 105% conversion of net income.
We continue to make progress on reducing our working capital across the business. Strong focused execution, improve working capital as of a revenue 80 basis points, excluding the impact of foreign exchange translation, this improvement coupled with our commitment to accelerate capital deployment about us increase the return of capital to shareholders by 24% in 2015.
That includes our fourth consecutive dividend increase in many years and a record $175 million of share repurchases. 
Turning to Slide 7, I'll cover our fourth quarter performance.
During the fourth quarter, we booked orders of $913 million, up 1% organically. I'll cover our performance by segment in a few minutes. For now, I'll focus my commentary on our ending backlog. 
We ended 2016 with total backlog of $760 million. Excluding foreign exchange translation impact backlog is up about 4%. Of the total, roughly $575 million is due to ship in 2016 and $335 million is due to ship in the first quarter. Excluding the impact of FX translation, our current year backlog is down 2%. 
Jumping back to the fourth quarter results, we generated revenue of $994 million, down 5% versus the prior year, including a $70 million headwind from foreign exchange translation. On an organic basis, revenue was up 2%.
From an end market perspective, we saw a significant strength in both public utility and residential. Revenue from the public utility end market was up 8% with double digit growth in the U.S., Asia and the Middle East. Project deliveries on an improved U.S. market coupled with share gains drove our performance across these regions. Residential was up 10%, primarily driven by market strength and share gains in the U.S. where we have about 50% of our customer base. 
Commercial was flat for the quarter, but against a tough prior year comparison of 8% growth. The story within commercial remains the same. We continue to benefit from a steady recovery in growth within the U.S. institutional building sector. The industrial end market was down 2% due to the aforementioned oil and gas headwinds. Agriculture was down 12%.
Operating margin was flat at 14.7%, but up 20 basis points excluding the headwind from foreign exchange translation. Cost reductions including Lean Six Sigma, global procurement and business simplification savings offset inflation driving 140 basis point improvement in segment margins. 
Volume leverage on the 2% organic growth was more than offset by unfavorable mix. Wrapping up on the consolidated results, solid organic revenue growth and execution against our cost reduction initiatives resulted in EPS of $0.60, an increase of 3% before the unfavorable impact of foreign exchange translation. 
Now let me provide more detail for each of our reporting segments. Please turn to Slide 8.
Water Infrastructure recorded orders of $559 million, up 2% organically. A couple of business mix dynamics worth highlighting. First, treatment orders grew more than 20%, including a large $20 million project order in Saudi Arabia as well as an increase in both North American project activity and win rates.
Nearly offsetting order growth was the overall declining in our dewatering business, again, reflecting the oil and gas weakness. Our book to bill ratio was 0.89 in the quarter, the same as last year. 
Overall, we exited the quarter with backlog of $544 million, up 8% on an organic basis. Of this amount, approximately $430 million is due to ship in 2016 with $230 million shipping in the first quarter. This leaves us with longer term project backlog shippable in 2017 and beyond of $115 million. This is a 48% increase over what we have seen last year on an organic basis. While this is a relatively small portion of our revenue, it is a leading indicator of market health and trend stability and provide some confidence in our generally short cycle business. 
We reported revenue of $629 million, up 1% on an organic basis. Regionally, we saw growth led by the U.S. in emerging markets, up 4% and 5%, respectively. Western Europe grew a modest 1% and Canada declined 21% due to the impact of oil and gas weakness. 
I will further summarize our revenue performance as follows: transport application, which includes our water and wastewater pump dewatering business were up 2% overall. Public utility water and wastewater pump sales and services grew 11% during the quarter, demonstrating both healthy market conditions and the strength of our Flygt brand, which continues to increase at share position. We also saw a double digit growth in the public utility sector for our dewatering business, driven by a relatively large product delivery and to a lesser extent, disaster recovery services in the U.S. and U.K. 
And as we have addressed, the unfavorable impact of oil and gas dewatering applications were down nearly 40% in the quarter. Test applications finished the year with a strong, up 4% with particular strength in Europe, up 9% with growth driven by industrial lab applications and several wastewater facility projects in the Nordic countries. 
Additionally, our delivery of critical analytical instrumentation used in China's River Cleanup project drove local revenue growth 24%. Finally, treatment revenue was down 3% as we lapped a few large water project deliveries in Latin America partially offsetting these headwinds for growth in the Middle East.
We are reporting operating income for our Water Infrastructure segment of $110 million and a record quarterly operating margin of 17.5%. Performance was driven by the increase in cost reductions of $19 million driven by sourcing and Lean initiatives as well as $2 million in restructuring savings.
This increase was able to more than offset labor and material and overhead inflation as well as the unfavorable mix driven by lower dewatering rental volumes. 
Let's turn to Slide 9. Applied water recorded orders of $354 million, down 1% organically. As a reminder, this compares with 9% growth in the fourth quarter of 2014. Our book to bill ratio was 0.97 in the quarter, which is in the range we have seen over the last 4 years. 
Overall, we exited the quarter with backlog of $172 million. Of this amount, about $105 million is due to ship in the first quarter 2016, down approximately 14% on a constant currency basis, which we expect will make growth in the first quarter.
Applied water reported revenue of $365 million, up 3% on an organic basis. Regionally, we saw a strong growth in the developed markets with the U.S. and Western Europe up 5% and 4%, respectively. Emerging markets declined 4%. As expected, our biggest headwind came from China, which is down 18% after posting 16% growth over the first 9 months of the year.
I'll further summarize our revenue performance as follows: building services grew 3% as we continue to benefit from the U.S. institutional building market on the commercial side and market share gains in residential. Growth in the commercial building market was muted overall by weakness in China. Industrial water grew 5%, largely driven by project strength in the U.S. and modestly improving conditions in project shipments in Europe. 
Lastly, irrigation which represents less than 10% of applied water revenue declined 12%, driven by unfavorable weather conditions and the lapping of a strong quarter in 2014 when we delivered 25% growth. Operating margin declined 10 basis point year over year to 13.4%, including 20 basis points of headwind from foreign exchange translation. 
Material labor in overhead inflation and unfavorable mix were notable headwinds this quarter, partially offset by cost reductions.
Despite volume leverage on 3% organic growth, unfavorable mix associated with a single industrial project significantly impacted our margin performance this quarter. The applied water portion of this project was sold in a negative margin, however, the project margin for Xylem overall was positive and reflected in the Water Infrastructure segment. 
Now let's turn to Slide 10  to cover the company's full year performance by segment. Let me start first with a Water Infrastructure segment. Revenue was $2.2 billion, up 1% organically driven primarily by growth    growing strength in the public utility end market and the continued build out on water and wastewater infrastructure in emerging markets. We grew 1% in industrial, excluding the significant oil and gas headwind. Operating margin declined 10 basis points year over year to 14.2%.
While cost reductions more than offset inflation in the year, volume leverage on the 1% organic growth did not compensate for the unfavorable mix impact attributable to the significant decline in rental services to the oil and gas market. 
Moving onto the Applied Water segment. Revenue was $1.4  billion, up 3% organically due to strength in the U.S. commercial and residential markets as well as growth in industrial water applications despite facing significant oil and gas headwinds.
In commercial, 4% growth was driven by an improved U.S. institutional building market. Residential also grew 4%, a strong performance came from improvement in the home construction market and market share gains. Partially offsetting this growth was weakness in the agriculture end market, which is down 8% due to unfavorable weather conditions and the lapping of a strong prior year. 
Operating margin decreased 10 basis points year over year to 13.9% due to unfavorable foreign exchange relation impact. Excluding this impact, adjusted operating margin increased 20 basis points as cost reductions and volume leverage more than offset inflation and unfavorable mix. 
Please turn to Slide 11 and I will cover the company's financial position. Xylem maintains a strong cash position with a balance of $680 million at the end of December. We remain committed to our balanced capital deployment strategy, which is to maintain and grow the business while enhancing shareholder returns through dividends and share repurchases. 
During the fourth quarter, we paid $25 million in dividends and purchased $50 million in shares. We generated $165 million of free cash flow in the fourth quarter, largely reflecting improved working capital performance. Relative to the prior year our free cash flow performance improved by $44 million. 
Lastly, our return on invested capital decreased by 30 basis points to 10.6%, which is primarily due to unfavorable foreign exchange translation. 
Now please turn to Slide 12 and I'll it back over to Patrick to cover our 2016 expectations.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Shank. As I said earlier, we believe we are well positioned to make significant progress against our top priorities in 2016 in order to drive long term profitable growth at Xylem. We're driving substantial changes at Xylem that strengthens ou
componenttext:
Thank you, Shank. 
As I said earlier, we believe we are well positioned to make significant progress against our top priorities in 2016 in order to drive long term profitable growth at Xylem. We're driving substantial changes at Xylem that strengthens our commercial capabilities taking specific actions to improve our customers experience at each touch point we have with them. This includes driving more expertise through industry verticals selling and simplifying our commercial processes. 
We have focused plans to accelerate growth in emerging markets, targeting increased investments of about $30 million in the Middle East, China and India. We plan to increase our R&D investment in 2016 by 30 to 50 basis points to advance innovation. And as we drive our continuous improvement work deepen into the organization, we expect our lean and global procurement initiatives to generate growth savings of $120 million, an increase of roughly 20% year over year. 
The growth rates I refer to on this slide all exclude the anticipated negative foreign exchange impacts. Looking at the year ahead, we expect to generate faster than market growth, delivering 2016 organic revenue growth of 2% to 4%. The recently completed acquisitions are expected to add an additional 1% of revenue growth.
Given that we expect stable conditions across roughly 90% of our portfolio, including growth across all geographic regions, we believe we're position to exceed market growth despite the ongoing headwinds from oil and gas and mining. Our adjusted operating margin is expected to growth in the range of 50 to 80 basis points overall despite roughly 20 basis points of margin dilution from the acquisitions of name in Thailand. This delusion is driven by purchase price accounting impacts such as noncash intangible amortization. Excluding these diluted impacts of acquisition, our operating margin is expected to expand by 70 to 100 basis points. We anticipate generating earnings per share of $1.95 to $2.05 which excludes restructuring and realignment of cost of about $25 million but this projection does include $0.04 of negative foreign currency translation impact. Excluding foreign exchange impact, EPS growth is expected to be in the range of 8% to 13%. Finally, we will continue to execute a disciplined approach to capital deployment, which is expected to result in free cash flow conversion greater than 100%. This also contemplates expected CapEx in the range of $120 million to $125 million. Please turn to Slide 13.
This slide outlines our expectations for 2016 organic revenue by end of market. Industrial, which represents 44% of total revenue is expected to be flat to up low single digits. This projection assumes low single digit growth in light industrial applications and double digit declines in oil and gas and mining applications. The public utility sector, which constitutes 33% of our total revenue, is expected to grow at a mid single digit rate. Here, we anticipate growth led by the U.S. and continued investment across emerging markets. We also expect market conditions in Europe to remain stable and at the U.K.'s multiyear 6 cycle of infrastructure investment, accelerates late in the half of the year. 
For the commercial market, we see growth in the mid single digit range. Our expectation is that growth in the U.S. institutional building market continues to be here and conditions in Europe modestly improved. Lastly, while we expect urbanization to drive growth in emerging markets such as the Middle East, we also anticipate weaker conditions in China. Residential should grow in the low to mid single digit range given by strength in the U.S. albeit at lower levels seen in 2015.
We also expect continued low single digit growth in Europe. Finally, agriculture would likely see a modest recovery from the significant weather events in 2015. 
Please turn to Slide 14 and Shashank will provide some calendarization insight for the year.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Patrick. As we have done in prior years, I'll highlight the seasonal profile of our business which you can see on the left of the slide and our prospective on 2016 on the right. As for the first quarter 2016, we expect 2% organic growth coupled
componenttext:
Thanks, Patrick. As we have done in prior years, I'll highlight the seasonal profile of our business which you can see on the left of the slide and our prospective on 2016 on the right. 
As for the first quarter 2016, we expect 2% organic growth coupled with approximately 1% growth on acquisition. Foreign exchange translation is anticipated to be a 4% headwind. As for operating margin, we anticipate it to be flat year over year as the oil and gas and mining headwinds will continue to office volume leverage and cost savings. Our expectations also assume a modest level of feast investment for growth initiatives.
We are assuming that both global procurement and lean savings expiring through the year whereby we realigned about $20 million on go savings in the first quarter and expect to deliver about $120 million for the full year. 
Now I'll turn the call back over to Patrick for closing comments. Please turn to Slide 15.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Shashank. So we had a strong finish in 2015 as we face some challenging conditions. Again, I want to thank our team for their performance as their focused execution against our strategic priorities helped us to deliver on the commitments we set fo
componenttext:
Thanks, Shashank. So we had a strong finish in 2015 as we face some challenging conditions. Again, I want to thank our team for their performance as their focused execution against our strategic priorities helped us to deliver on the commitments we set forth at the beginning of 2015. I am confident in their ability and commitment to deliver organic growth targets and margin expansion opportunities. 
Xylem is in a very strong financial position and we will continue to drive our balanced accelerated capital deployment plans. I am very encouraged as I look ahead to 2016 and beyond. No doubt, there are challenges in the near term but I am confident that  our team will continue to execute with operational discipline to drive our success. That commitment and focus will provide the foundation for future growth for Xylem and our shareholders. 
With that, operator, we're ready to open the line for questions.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Deane Dray with from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Deane Dray with from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you really checked all the boxes this quarter. If I look at it, in line EPS, you got free cash flow, you do a dividend boost, you do buybacks, you get a deal done, so hopefully, you still have some feel good left for the rest of the quarters in 2016. S
componenttext: So you really checked all the boxes this quarter. If I look at it, in line EPS, you got free cash flow, you do a dividend boost, you do buybacks, you get a deal done, so hopefully, you still have some feel good left for the rest of the quarters in 2016. So anyway, a question I wanted to focus on first is if we should hear a bit more about this large shipment that you disclosed in the applied Water business because it sounds as though the orders and for applied in Water Infrastructure, which is good see that suggestion during cross selling, but the way the P&L gets tallied, applied ended up showing a negative margin. So kind of put this project into context, is this solution selling? Do you have other business like this? How do you net the 2 out, how does that project look?

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the comments, Deane. We appreciate it. On this is project, this is a project actually that has been in backlog for multiple years and there has been some delays in the customer jobsite in terms of ultimately delivering it. So it's been a backlo
componenttext: Thanks for the comments, Deane. We appreciate it. On this is project, this is a project actually that has been in backlog for multiple years and there has been some delays in the customer jobsite in terms of ultimately delivering it. So it's been a backlog for more than a couple of years. The margin was net positive and attractive for us. I wouldn't say we have other projects like this that are out there. I mean, it was fine. It was an element of some solutions sell. It was a bundled offering for an LNG application, but again, it's a bit of a one off. It's a large project and it's kind of spanned over a few quarters here in terms of shipping it out.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And the question    the follow up question is not so much Xylem specific, but I'm really struck by and interested in hearing on your comments on the ramifications for this water crisis unfolding in Flint, Michigan and again it's on the front page
componenttext: Got it. And the question    the follow up question is not so much Xylem specific, but I'm really struck by and interested in hearing on your comments on the ramifications for this water crisis unfolding in Flint, Michigan and again it's on the front page of the journal today. So how do you feel    what's your sense of what happens and the response within the municipal water community? There's going to be congressional pressures here? What went wrong? What does this mean for the need for smart water networks, I know that's been a big focus for you. How do you think this place out? And what are the ramifications for spending on this backlog in U.S. Water Infrastructure?

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, it's a great question, Dean and as I mentioned in my opening comments, I mean, it's obviously a tragic situation there in Flint. As you will recall, we have similar situations or may be different causes in Toledo not long before that and you've got
componenttext: Sure, it's a great question, Dean and as I mentioned in my opening comments, I mean, it's obviously a tragic situation there in Flint. As you will recall, we have similar situations or may be different causes in Toledo not long before that and you've got a number of these floods    flooding conditions that we see from a resilience standpoint. There's infrastructure that needs to be invested in. As you been following the water space for a long time, it's always difficult for any of us to predict the timing of when this will unlock some of the pent up demand that's out there. But I do believe that there will likely be increased regulatory scrutiny. I think that will also lead to some increase in backlog movement in various communities across the U.S. It always seems to happen slower than any of us think it should occur so it's difficult to predict kind of what time frame we think it will begin to free up. But I do think this will be a collection of flashpoints that begins to move forward.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's really helpful. Let me sneak one question in the deal is another focus in the water analytics side, hydrology, what's the pipeline look for M&A?
componenttext: That's really helpful. Let me sneak one question in the deal is another focus in the water analytics side, hydrology, what's the pipeline look for M&A?

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we're excited by both the high pack [ph] and the Tideland acquisitions. They are very nice additions to our portfolio and really tie in nicely with the capabilities we already have in the analytics space in that area of hydrology. The pipeline ove
componenttext: Yes, so we're excited by both the high pack [ph] and the Tideland acquisitions. They are very nice additions to our portfolio and really tie in nicely with the capabilities we already have in the analytics space in that area of hydrology. The pipeline overall, I mean, that's only 1 vertical obviously that we're focusing in on. If I go back to Investor Day, we talked about smart water infrastructure or systems intelligence. We talked about advanced treatment in industrial and we talked about makings that we defended and protected some of our unassailable kind of core franchises. So the pipeline continues to build. It's very attractive. It's pretty broad, indeed. As you know, it's always difficult to predict the timing when things come forward. It always takes 2 to tango. But I'm very encouraged by the work the team's done to further build out that pipeline and lines up nicely with the value mapping work that we shared at Investor Day.

componenttext: Just a couple of follow up on the restructuring actions, the $25 million. Can you break this down? And is this incremental to 2017 and '18, how should we think about it? And then second question is this your mention of private capital, I mean, overall in it? I was hoping if you could elaborate on that.

componenttext: This is Shank. I'll take the first question. As far as $25 million, it is incremental and it generates about $8 million in 2016 probably back end loaded to in the second half. As far as where those actions are, it's in the areas of footprint. It's in the areas of the G&A and business simplification initiatives we have outlined during Investor Day.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: On your second question around unlocking private capital, our role there is not necessarily being actively involved in financing of those type of activities. What I'm alluding to there we're involved in, it's our role as a thought leader in the water spac
componenttext: On your second question around unlocking private capital, our role there is not necessarily being actively involved in financing of those type of activities. What I'm alluding to there we're involved in, it's our role as a thought leader in the water space, we're involved in a couple of efforts with other organizations in helping further movement around things like public private partnerships, other models that exist in other parts of the world that are not quite commonplace in the U.S. We believe there's a virtual for the private sector to play in driving attractive investments there. And so helping in some of the education effort in that area is really the role that I'm referring to.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Nathan Jones with Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Nathan Jones with Stifel.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Pat, in your prepared remarks, you talked about the public utility market and I think you commented that U.S., Middle East and Asia were up double digits. And did not make any reference to Europe given Europe is the biggest end market there, coul
componenttext: I think, Pat, in your prepared remarks, you talked about the public utility market and I think you commented that U.S., Middle East and Asia were up double digits. And did not make any reference to Europe given Europe is the biggest end market there, could you give us some color on what you're seeing in the public utility market in Europe and what your expectations are for 2016 there?

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, yes. So we saw Europe really stabilize over the back half of the year and I would describe it as stable at this point. I mean, it is still a mixed bag. I would say we have not seen the continued deterioration in the southern part of Europe that we'd
componenttext: Sure, yes. So we saw Europe really stabilize over the back half of the year and I would describe it as stable at this point. I mean, it is still a mixed bag. I would say we have not seen the continued deterioration in the southern part of Europe that we'd experienced in the kind of first 3 quarters of the year. That stabilizes well. So I think we're on fairly solid footing. One of the things that will benefit us in 2016, of course, is the impact in the U.K. of the infrastructure investment cycle there that you're all probably quite familiar with. That cycle was launched, I think, April 1 of this past year. It takes about 15 months or so for all the engineering and design and spec work to happen in the part of customers. And then we really begin to see the revenue come our way in the late '16 through kind of 2018 or so. But I think net net, it's stable in Europe and kind of low single digit growth for 2016.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if we just look at the industrial, part of industrial, I think we're all fairly comfortable that oil and gas and mining are very good in 2016. You're talking about low single digit growth there which you'll need to get to flat or up slightly. Ca
componenttext: Okay. And if we just look at the industrial, part of industrial, I think we're all fairly comfortable that oil and gas and mining are very good in 2016. You're talking about low single digit growth there which you'll need to get to flat or up slightly. Can you talk about the different dynamics that are going on within that market that have you able to grow in what's probably a flat to may be slightly down global industrial market?

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. That's a great question. I'd say first of all, when you think about the nature of what the light industrial sector is, customers in that area are quite diverse. But across the board, they are very much focused in on energy efficiency to reduce their
componenttext: Sure. That's a great question. I'd say first of all, when you think about the nature of what the light industrial sector is, customers in that area are quite diverse. But across the board, they are very much focused in on energy efficiency to reduce their operating costs. Our volume there is not really like it would be in heavy industrial, it's not really tied to factory output. But it's rather more of an ongoing minimal operating costs. These are not large capital outlays that are requiring the part of our customers and so it doesn't tend to be big on the radar screen. Other than, again, they play arrow, these products play a role in helping them reduce their operating cost through energy efficiency. So we think we're pretty resilient. I think that was demonstrated through to 2015 when that part of the business, again, was up 2% organically and we've seen really nothing here in the latter part of '15 or early '16 that would change our view on that.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: How much of that light industrial market is driven by the regulatory environment rather than the operating environment?
componenttext: How much of that light industrial market is driven by the regulatory environment rather than the operating environment?

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't say it's a large driver in that area. I mean, I would say that as some of the energy efficiency regulations that have already been put in place in the EU come to the U.S. over the course of the next few years, then certainly, there would be som
componenttext: I wouldn't say it's a large driver in that area. I mean, I would say that as some of the energy efficiency regulations that have already been put in place in the EU come to the U.S. over the course of the next few years, then certainly, there would be some sort of a driver that. But I wouldn't say it's a big driver today. It's more than just again managing your operating cost.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ryan Connors with Boenning and Scattergood.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ryan Connors with Boenning and Scattergood.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to talk a little bit about the kind of price cost situation in this environment if you might expand on it for us. Obviously, some of the raw material prices have come down and if you could talk about that impact on your P&L vis à vis what you're
componenttext: I wanted to talk a little bit about the kind of price cost situation in this environment if you might expand on it for us. Obviously, some of the raw material prices have come down and if you could talk about that impact on your P&L vis à vis what you're seeing on the pricing side, that would be helpful.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Shank. From a pricing perspective, we expect fairly neutral condition so flattish pricing 2015 going into 2016. Clearly, we'd like to see more price in 2016 but it will be challenged based on our current commodity environment, so that's a    as I
componenttext: This is Shank. From a pricing perspective, we expect fairly neutral condition so flattish pricing 2015 going into 2016. Clearly, we'd like to see more price in 2016 but it will be challenged based on our current commodity environment, so that's a    as I said, it's flattish but from a savings perspective, that does help because we do buy a lot of raw material. And the current environment helps drive more out of global procurement and our target in 2016 is for higher cost out from global procurement perspective as well as business simplification.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would just add, Ryan, I think that as we've talked a little bit in the past, there's probably less than 10% of our revenue that is in end markets that are more challenged from a pricing standpoint, that really being in ag and resi part of the market. We
componenttext: I would just add, Ryan, I think that as we've talked a little bit in the past, there's probably less than 10% of our revenue that is in end markets that are more challenged from a pricing standpoint, that really being in ag and resi part of the market. We continue to manage through that and maintain, I think, a very good discipline from a pricing standpoint. The area that we would suggest over time you would expect the supply demand favorability to work in our direction would be on the public utility sector. But we're still so early in the recovery there that we're not really counting on that kind of price dynamic in 2016.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so would you hazard a guesstimate at what kind of a basis points tailwind raw materials could be to the margins if you are able to say, hold your price flat, in aggregate?
componenttext: And so would you hazard a guesstimate at what kind of a basis points tailwind raw materials could be to the margins if you are able to say, hold your price flat, in aggregate?

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would suspect it's probably about 20 to 30 basis points.
componenttext: I would suspect it's probably about 20 to 30 basis points.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. That's helpful. And then my other question, just really big picture, Patrick. You issue your '16 guidance today and talked a lot about some of the puts and takes and some of the positives. But what's your view as kind of the biggest risk facto
componenttext: Okay, okay. That's helpful. And then my other question, just really big picture, Patrick. You issue your '16 guidance today and talked a lot about some of the puts and takes and some of the positives. But what's your view as kind of the biggest risk factor that could cause things to not play out the way you've laid out today as you look out over the next 11 months here?

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I would say that the area that we kind of called out in our prepared comments is clearly going to be    we've already built some of this into our outlook and that is continued downward pressure in both oil and gas and mining. Again, those are now on
componenttext: Sure. I would say that the area that we kind of called out in our prepared comments is clearly going to be    we've already built some of this into our outlook and that is continued downward pressure in both oil and gas and mining. Again, those are now only 8% of our total revenues. It's not a large portion of our business. But certainly, if we saw mining drop off dramatically, then that would put pressure on our top line. But we feel that we reflective that in the bottom end of the organic growth range. In terms of profitability, again, as we mentioned in our comments, these businesses are very high profit margin. And for us, again, we feel that we have taken into consideration in our guidance but obviously, there were other cost out actions that we would take in the event that we sold that and that's certainly something we learned this past year in our dewatering business.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chip Moore with Canaccord.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chip Moore with Canaccord.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we touched on new trends in the U.S. and Europe maybe we can move to emerging markets a bit. What can you say about infrastructure spending holds up over there? And maybe follow up, talk about some of the softness you've seen in the commercial side.
componenttext: As we touched on new trends in the U.S. and Europe maybe we can move to emerging markets a bit. What can you say about infrastructure spending holds up over there? And maybe follow up, talk about some of the softness you've seen in the commercial side.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. On the public utility side for emerging markets, the real key drivers there certainly at the moment and we're still seeing this in our coating activity and bidding activity is the, again, the fact that in our largest emerging markets, the whole issu
componenttext: Sure. On the public utility side for emerging markets, the real key drivers there certainly at the moment and we're still seeing this in our coating activity and bidding activity is the, again, the fact that in our largest emerging markets, the whole issue of access to water and sustainability there are policy issues and concerns whether it be in China, whether it be Middle East, whether it be in India. And so, we're certainly not seeing any significant downward pressure there or slowing down of those large projects. But that certainly is something we're keeping a very close mindful eye on. As we did indicate in our guidance around emerging markets and as we saw them in the fourth quarter, certainly, a significant headwind in pressure on the commercial building side especially in China as well as some of the impact of lower commodity prices on the industrial business there in China as well as in Latin America. So again, in our guidance for 2016, we feel that we've taken a pretty balanced approach in that area. But again, we will keep a close eye on that and modulate our cost base accordingly across the rest of the portfolio.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to add a little bit of color to that, for emerging markets in 2015, we delivered about 17% growth and it did slowed down in Q4 primarily due to China. As we look towards 2016, we kind of moderated that to a mid single digit growth and certainly w
componenttext: And just to add a little bit of color to that, for emerging markets in 2015, we delivered about 17% growth and it did slowed down in Q4 primarily due to China. As we look towards 2016, we kind of moderated that to a mid single digit growth and certainly we, factored in the slowness in China especially on the commercial building side. But then, we got investments going in in Middle East and South Africa as we talked about as well as large project delivers it India that helped the overall market picture.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Maybe just a follow up on oil and gas. Dewatering comps get better in the second half, 40% decline this year. I think you called out double digit decline next year can you maybe can talk about sensitivities and what you're baking in there for declin
componenttext: Okay. Maybe just a follow up on oil and gas. Dewatering comps get better in the second half, 40% decline this year. I think you called out double digit decline next year can you maybe can talk about sensitivities and what you're baking in there for declines in oil and gas?

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we built in about a 30% impact in decline first half and that stabilizes over the course of the full year. And so it blends out in that kind of low teen decline for all of '15. And we've also factored in about a 10% decline in mining in that outlo
componenttext: Yes, so we built in about a 30% impact in decline first half and that stabilizes over the course of the full year. And so it blends out in that kind of low teen decline for all of '15. And we've also factored in about a 10% decline in mining in that outlook.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

So for the year, off the top of my head, I would say it's down 13%, 15% or so for the year. And in terms of size, it's about $150 million in revenue.

componenttext: Okay, great.

componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Konigsberg with Vertical Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Konigsberg with Vertical Research.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This might sound like a little bit of a crazy question considering the backdrop but under the scenario where oil prices do say improve just modestly. Do you get a supply response out of the U.S. I'm just curious, maybe 2 things. Where do you think that oi
componenttext: This might sound like a little bit of a crazy question considering the backdrop but under the scenario where oil prices do say improve just modestly. Do you get a supply response out of the U.S. I'm just curious, maybe 2 things. Where do you think that oil prices actually need to go to actually initiate a supplier response? And how quickly would you guys benefit if that was to happen?

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brian. I would say    I mean, I wouldn't want to put the dollar amount out there in terms of oil price to go there. But the key is it needs to be substantial enough that there's a meaningful increase in oil rigs, that's really the high correlator for
componenttext: Yes, Brian. I would say    I mean, I wouldn't want to put the dollar amount out there in terms of oil price to go there. But the key is it needs to be substantial enough that there's a meaningful increase in oil rigs, that's really the high correlator for us. And I think also given our heavy exposure on the frac ing side, again, I think that we would need to see a pretty notable move upwards in oil prices for us to be able to see a meaningful recovery there. So I don't want to sound to sour on that because I do believe that once we get at it and there will be other sometime down the road. The teams in that part of our balance business have done a fantastic job at managing the cost me so we will certainly see a very healthy incremental leverage when we see any growth there. But we're not counting on any of that here in 2016.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, understood. And next, could you touch a little bit more on the free cash flow you're looking for a 100% plus conversion. Maybe you could give us the outlook as far as what are the kind of meaningful contributors. Obviously, you've got DNA. I mean, a
componenttext: Sure, understood. And next, could you touch a little bit more on the free cash flow you're looking for a 100% plus conversion. Maybe you could give us the outlook as far as what are the kind of meaningful contributors. Obviously, you've got DNA. I mean, are you counting on working capital coming through. Or are there other items we should be thinking about?

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I could take that one. It is over 100% and the drivers there are the de novo generation of cash plus. On the working capital side, we showed good progress in the second half, that momentum continues and that momentum will continue through the full year so
componenttext: I could take that one. It is over 100% and the drivers there are the de novo generation of cash plus. On the working capital side, we showed good progress in the second half, that momentum continues and that momentum will continue through the full year so we expect    that's why we expect over 100% working capital areas such as we had good progress on inventory and accounts payable. On the AR side, we got hurt a little bit with the heavy shipment in December, but that scenario we continue to as far as receivables and we saw a good progress there in the fourth quarter as well.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Great. If I could just slip one last in. What's the updated status on the CFO search?

componenttextpreview: Sure. So we've had a lot of interest in the role, interviewed a large number of experienced public company CFO candidates. We're down now to the short strokes and so I'm confident we're going to be announcing something here in the very near future.
componenttext: Sure. So we've had a lot of interest in the role, interviewed a large number of experienced public company CFO candidates. We're down now to the short strokes and so I'm confident we're going to be announcing something here in the very near future.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Nick Prendergast with BB&T.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had a quick question on your emerging markets and I know you touched on this in the prepared remarks. You know that the growth was 7% in the year, it slowed down to I believe around 2% in Q4. What exactly drove that again?
componenttext: I just had a quick question on your emerging markets and I know you touched on this in the prepared remarks. You know that the growth was 7% in the year, it slowed down to I believe around 2% in Q4. What exactly drove that again?

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that was predominantly the sharp decline that we had in commercial building and industrial in China in the quarter and we also had a tough prior year comp as well. We had quite a large growth in fourth quarter last year in emerging markets.
componenttext: Yes, that was predominantly the sharp decline that we had in commercial building and industrial in China in the quarter and we also had a tough prior year comp as well. We had quite a large growth in fourth quarter last year in emerging markets.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. If I heard correctly in the Q&A, you kind of moderated your view in emerging markets from the 7% in '15 to somewhere around mid single digits in '16. Is that correct? What gives you confidence that will continue if you don't continue to suffer from
componenttext: Okay. If I heard correctly in the Q&A, you kind of moderated your view in emerging markets from the 7% in '15 to somewhere around mid single digits in '16. Is that correct? What gives you confidence that will continue if you don't continue to suffer from this China slow down or whatever?

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. That is correct in terms of what we laid out. What we see there is confidence. First of all, I would say, I wouldn't focus too much on any 1 quarter large part of business in emerging markets is still projects given this new greenfield things and th
componenttext: Sure. That is correct in terms of what we laid out. What we see there is confidence. First of all, I would say, I wouldn't focus too much on any 1 quarter large part of business in emerging markets is still projects given this new greenfield things and those can be choppy in terms of quarter to quarter movement or year over year comparisons. But again, we think that it is continued strength in public utility in China over the course of the full year and it's the benefits that we're seeing from investments we're seeing in the Middle East. And then lastly, you may recall that last year, we announced a $40 million project win in India and a large piece of that ships out in in 2016.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll take that one. As far as from a euro perspective, which is a big headline a year ago, the euro today what it was last year where we see the foreign exchange impact in 2016 as probably the British pound, the Aussie dollar, the Canadian dollar imp
componenttext: Yes. I'll take that one. As far as from a euro perspective, which is a big headline a year ago, the euro today what it was last year where we see the foreign exchange impact in 2016 as probably the British pound, the Aussie dollar, the Canadian dollar impacting us as well as the emerging market currencies there's some softness which kind of blends in the fourth quarter is still there and taking that income of that's where we see the challenge. As long as the euro holds, we don't see the headwind from the euro like we did a year ago.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: I mean, if we're getting into the situation dollars going to weaken going forward we can versus the euro, how is that going to benefit you guys?

componenttextpreview: And I just jump in here? Last year, we gave kind of a rule of thumb schedule if you would. Based on the outlook or based on where we are in terms of the calendar, you basically think about it net, net, for every set move in the euro, you got about $0.01 b
componenttext: And I just jump in here? Last year, we gave kind of a rule of thumb schedule if you would. Based on the outlook or based on where we are in terms of the calendar, you basically think about it net, net, for every set move in the euro, you got about $0.01 benefit to us or headwind to us at the bottom line. So it's about $0.01 for $0.01 for the full year.

headline: Xylem Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
